Description: A quality control tool for high throughput raw sequence data.
Features: It generates quality reports for NGS data and gives pass/fail results for the following checks: Per base sequence quality, Per sequence quality scores, Per base sequence content, Per base GC content, Per sequence GC content, Per base N content, Sequence length distribution, Sequence duplication levels, Overrepresented sequences, Kmer content. It also has a Graphic User Interface.
Strength: It is easy to use; provides visualization in HTML reports; can be used on Illumina, PacBio, 454 reads.
{\"value\" : \"single-end\" , \"text\":: single-ended;  {"value":"paired-end", "text":"Apply to forward and reverse strands separately."}

Description: The FASTX-Toolkit is a collection of command line tools for short-reads FASTA/FASTQ files preprocessing.
Features: The sub-command "fastx_trimmer" can be used to shorten reads (removing barcodes or noise) in FASTQ files . The sub-command "fastqx_clipper" can remove sequencing adapters or linkers.
Strength: Besides "fastx_trimmer" and "fastx_clipper" in this toolkit, there are multiple tools and commands for processing FASTA/FASTQ files. It can also be integrated and used on the web-based bioinformatics platform Galaxy.
Limitation: Last updated in 2010. {"value": "Be ware of the older base quality encoding. ", "link" : "https://wikis.utexas.edu/display/bioiteam/FASTQ+Manipulation+Tools" }

Description: A flexible read trimming tool for Illumina NGS data.
Features: It can trim adapter sequences, remove low-quality reads and bases.
Strength: It is designed as more pair-aware for paired-end data. The authors found trimmomatic to run faster than cutadapt and FASTX-Toolkit.  ({"value":"see Trimmomatic paper","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4103590/"})

Description: Cutadapt finds and removes adapter sequences, primers, poly-A tails and other types of unwanted sequences from high-throughput sequencing reads.
Features: Cutadapt helps with various trimming tasks by finding the adapter or primer sequences in an error-tolerant way. It can also modify and filter reads in various ways. Adapter sequences can contain IUPAC wildcard characters. Also, paired-end reads and even colorspace data are supported. If you want, you can also just demultiplex your input data, without removing adapter sequences at all ({"value":"see manual","link":"https://media.readthedocs.org/pdf/cutadapt/stable/cutadapt.pdf"}).
Strength: It supports 454, Illumina and SOLiD (colour space) data. It is used inside another tool called {"value":"Trim Galore","text":"https://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/trim_galore/"}, also a quality control tool by the FastQC team.

Description: A complete pipeline for ChIA-PET data analysis. The subcommand trimLinker is a tool to trim linker sequences in the pair-end fastq(.gz) files.
Features: trimLinker trims ChIA-PET reads using A/B linker sequences provided and generates trimming statistics.
Strength: ChIA-PET2 has a complete pipeline from raw sequence files to ChIA-PET interactions called. The subcommand trimLinker does fuzzy search and deals with both half linkers and bridge linkers (Note: ChIA-PET protocol papers with {"value": "1. half links", "link": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19890323"} and {"value": "2. bridge linkers", "link": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26686651"}). The mismatches-allowing strategy at the linker trimming step can rescue a large portion of paired-end tags (PETs).

Description: A complete and bias-correcting pipeline for ChIA-PET data analysis. Linkers are trimmed and filtered in stage 1.
Features: In stage 1, it deals with ChIA-PET data with half linkers and perform exact search of linkers for trimming.
Strength: Mango has a complete pipeline from raw sequence files to ChIA-PET significant interactions called.
Limitation: Does not deal with bridge linkers.

Description: ChIA-PET Tools is the first software for ChIA-PET data with a complete analysis pipeline. A substep in the command performs linker filtering on ChIA-PET data.
Features: The linker filtering step deals with ChIA-PET data with half linkers and perform exact search of linkers.
Strength: ChIA-PET Tool has a complete pipeline from raw sequence files to ChIA-PET significant interactions called.
Limitation: Does not deal with bridge linkers.

Software: Bowtie (also used by Mango and ChIA-PET Tool)
Description: An ultrafast memory-efficient short read aligner.
Features: It uses Burrows-Wheeler transform to create a permanent, reusable index of the genome.
Strength: It aligns short DNA sequences (reads) to the human genome at a rate of over 25 million 35-bp reads per hour. Bowtie indexes the genome with a Burrows-Wheeler index to keep its memory footprint small: typically about 2.2 GB for the human genome (2.9 GB for paired-end; {"value":"see Bowtie page", "link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/index.shtml"}). For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and/or more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"link","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Limitation: Bowtie does not support gapped alignments; there is an upper limit on read length (1024 bp).
Format_input: FASTQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Description: Bowtie 2 is an ultrafast and memory-efficient tool for aligning sequencing reads to long reference sequences.
Features: Bowtie2 first extracts "seed" substrings in reads, aligns seeds in an ungapped way, and then performs extension in a gapped way.
Strength: Bowtie 2 supports gapped, local, and paired-end alignment modes. It indexes the genome with an FM Index to keep its memory footprint small: for the human genome, its memory footprint is typically around 3.2 GB. For reads longer than about 50 bp, Bowtie 2 is generally faster, more sensitive, and uses less memory than Bowtie 1. It is particularly good at aligning reads of about 50 up to 100s or 1,000s of characters, and good at aligning to relatively long (i.e. mammalian) genomes.  {"value":"see Bowtie2 page","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/index.shtml"}
Limitation: For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"see this","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Format_input: FASTQ, QSEQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Software: BWA (also used by ChIA-PET2 and ChIA-PET Tool)
Description: BWA is a software package for mapping low-divergent sequences against a large reference genome.
Features: BWA uses a Burrows-Wheeler transform to create an index of the genome. It consists of three algorithms: BWA-backtrack, BWA-SW and BWA-MEM. The first algorithm is designed for Illumina sequence reads up to 100bp, while the other two are for longer sequences ranged from 70bp to 1Mbp. {"value":"link","link":"http://bio-bwa.sourceforge.net/bwa.shtml"}
Strength: BWA allows indels in alignment. BWA is used by {"value":"ENCODE DNase-seq pipeline", "link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/dnase_pipeline"} and {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"}.

Description: SAMtools: Utilities for the Sequence Alignment/Map (SAM) format.
Features: SAMtools has multiple commands for processing SAM/BAM files. The sub-command "SAMtools-flagstat" can be used to print statistics for SAM/BAM files using the {"value":"FLAG field","link":"https://samtools.github.io/hts-specs/SAMv1.pdf"}.

Description: ChIA-PET2 has a complete pipeline from raw sequences to significant interactions. Multiple QC metrics and plots will be generated along the analysis.
Features: It generates mapping QC metrics with plots, including linker trimming statistics, mapping statistics and PETs statistics.
Strength: ChIA-PET2 has a complete pipeline from raw sequence files to ChIA-PET interactions called.

Description: A complete pipeline for ChIA-PET data analysis. The subcommand removes duplicates in BEDPE data.
Features: Following duplication removal, the subcommand "buildTagAlign" prepares input for peak calling through MACS2.
Strength: ChIA-PET2 has a complete pipeline from raw sequence files to ChIA-PET interactions called.

Description: Mango provides a complete pipeline for ChIA-PET data analysis. Duplicates are removed in Mango-stage 3.
Features: In stage 3, duplicates are removed and reads are prepared for peak calling through MACS2.

Description: Picard is a set of command line tools for manipulating high-throughput sequencing (HTS) data and formats such as SAM/BAM/CRAM and VCF.
Features: It can summarize mapping statistics such as insert size, mapping score summary, and quality score summary. In particular, the subcommand Picard-MarkDuplicates can be used to mark or remove duplicated reads.
Limitation: MarkDuplicates uses coordinate information but not read sequence information.

Description: Model based analysis of ChIP-seq (MACS).
Features: It identifies genome-wide profiles of transcription factor binding sites or histone modification from ChIP-seq data; uses the read strand information with a local Poission model.
Strength: MACS2 is used by complete pipelines ChIA-PET2 and Mango. MACS can be ran in two modes: narrow mode for transcription factors and broad mode for histone modifications. It is used in {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"} and {"value":"Cistrome", "link": "http://cistrome.org/"}.

Description: ChIA-PET Tool is the first freely available software for ChIA-PET data with a complete analysis pipeline.
Features: Peak calling in this tool is implemented using a poisson model on the self-ligation PETs.

Description: A complete and bias-correcting pipeline for ChIA-PET data analysis.
Features: It uses the strand orientation information of PETs to classify self-ligation PETs and inter-ligation PETs.
Strength: Mango has a complete pipeline from raw sequence files to ChIA-PET significant interactions called.

step: Paired-End Tags classification and Interaction calling
Description: ChIA-PET Tool is the first freely available software for ChIA-PET data with a complete analysis pipeline.
Features: Paired-End Tags (PETs) are classified as self-ligation PETs and inter-ligation PETs, based on genomic distance.

step: Paired-End Tags classification and Interaction calling
Description: A complete pipeline for ChIA-PET data analysis. The subcommands pairToBed and bedpe2Interactoin are for detecting chromatin interactions.
Features: It does not set a hard threshold for calling self-ligation PETs, but uses the nearest peak distance and PET counts to determine that.
Strength: ChIA-PET2 has a complete pipeline from raw sequence files to ChIA-PET interactions called.

Description: Visualization of Hi-C data with genomic datasets.
Features: A tool with multiple functions to make static Hi-C data plots and additional tracks.
Strength: The complete pipeline ChIA-PET2 can build Hi-C style 2D contact matrix that is compatible with HiCPlotter. HiCPlotter also has a conversion tool bedToMatrix.py.

Description: Visualization and analysis software for Hi-C data.
Features: Juicebox allows users to zoom in and out of Hi-C maps interactively.
Strength: It can be used to view Hi-C, 5C and ChIA-PET data. Data can also be exported into matrix etc.

Description: Model based Interaction Calling from ChIA-PET data.
Features: MICC uses a mixture model for calling significant interactions. It tends to call more interactions than ChiaSig and Mango ({"value": "He et al., 2016", "link": "https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40484-016-0080-3"}).
Strength: It provides a MICCPERL script for PET format conversion. It is also one step in the complete pipeline ChIA-PET2. It deals with inter-chromosomal interactions. It shows high reproducibility when calling interactions from data replicates ({"value": "He et al., 2016", "link": "https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40484-016-0080-3"}.

Description: The first freely available software for ChIA-PET data with a complete analysis pipeline.
Features: The model uses a hypergeometric distribution to detect significant interactions.
Limitation: It assumes there is only random ligation noise and two paired genomic regions have same chance of interaction regardless of their genomic distance.

Description: A script for calculating significant interactions from ChIA-PET data.
Features: It takes into account the genomic distance between two anchors (genomic regions) and models the interaction frequency using the non-central hypergeometric distribution.
Strength: The original paper shows an improvement over ChIA-PET Tool using 5C data.
Limitation: It does not deal with inter-chromosomal interactions. The interactions called can be conservative. ({"value": "He et al., 2015", "link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26231426"})

Description: A complete, bias-correcting ChIA-PET analysis pipeline.
Features: The model considers genomic distance and strength (read depth) of ChIP-seq peaks. It uses a bionomial model to evaluate significance of interactions.
Strength: The model considers genomic distance and strength (read depth) of ChIP-seq peaks; The Mango paper found it generates interactions which are in agreement with Hi-C data better than those from ChIA-PET Tool and ChiaSig. ({ "value": "Phanstiel et al. 2015", "link": "https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/31/19/3092/211522"})
Limitation: It does not deal with inter-chromosomal interactions. Mango can be conservative when calling significant loops ({"value": "Li et al., 2017", "link": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27625391"}).

Description: When genotype data is available, the subcommand bedpe2Phased can be used to generate the allele-specific PETs.
Features: An optional analysis.
Strength: ChIA-PET2 provides a complete analysis pipeline from raw sequences to chromosome interactions.

Description: Identifying differential DNA loops from chromatin topology data.
Features: "A suite of tools for subsetting, visualizing, annotating, and statistically analyzing the results of one or more ChIA-PET experiments or other assays that infer chromatin loops" ({"value": "link", "link": "https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/diffloop.html"}). The tool calls {"value": "edgeR", "link":"https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/edgeR.html"} to test differential looping.
